12SM_2026/01-Proof-and-Logic/01---Revisi.title: 01 - Revision of Proof
12SM_2026/01-Proof-and-Logic/01---Revisi.content:
Revision of Proof
Quantification
For all (\forall)
A universal statement claims that a property holds for all members of a given set. Such a statement can be written using the quantifier ‘for all’. For example:

For all real numbers x and y, x^2+5y^2 \geqslant 2xy  or  \forall x,y \in \mathbb{R} ~ (x^2+5y^2 \geqslant 2xy)

To prove this a general argument that applies for all choices of x and y is required.
There exists (\exists)
An existence statement claims that a property holds for at least one member of a given set. Such a statement can be written using the quantifier ‘there exists’. For example:

There exists a triple of integers a,b,c such that a^2+b^2=c^2  or  \exists a,b,c\in \mathbb{Z}~(a^2+b^2=c^2)

To prove that this statement is true, we just need to give one instance.

Negation of Quantifiers
When negating a statement with a quantifier, the quantifiers must also change.

‘There exists’ becomes ‘For all’
‘For all’ becomes ‘There exists’

Example 1.1 Write down the negation of each of the following statements:
(a) For all natural numbers n, we have 2n\geqslant n+1
(b) There exists an integer m such that m^2=4 and m^3= 8
(c) For all real numbers x and y, if x<y, then x^2< y^2
hint: \neg (P \implies Q) = P \land \neg Q


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                





Disproving Statements
To disprove:

a universal statement, a single counterexample is required
an existence statement, a proof of the negation is required (which is a universal statement)

Example 1.2 Disprove the following:
(a) For all real numbers n, n^2 is either a multiple of 2 or 3.
(b) There exists a natural number n such that n^2+3n+2 is odd.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Revision-of-Proof---Ex1.2.excalidraw



Divisibility
Example 1.3 Let n\in \mathbb{Z}, prove that n^3-n is divisible by 3.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Revision-of-Proof---Ex1.3.excalidraw



Conditional Statements
P \implies Q (P implies Q)
P is the hypothesis, Q is the conclusion. Assume P to be true in order to prove.
Example 1.4 Prove that if n is odd, n^2-1 is divisible by 4.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Revision-of-Proof---Ex1.4.excalidraw



Contrapositive
Remember the contrapositive statement is true if the statement is true.
The contrapositive of P\implies Q is \neg Q \implies \neg P.
Example 1.5 Let n\in \mathbb{Z}, prove that if n^2+2n is odd, then n is odd.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Revision-of-Proof---Ex1.5.excalidraw



Contradiction
The basic outline of a proof by contradiction is:

Assume that the statement we want to prove is false.
Show that this assumption leads to mathematical nonsense.
Conclude that we were wrong to assume that the statement is false.
Conclude that the statement must be true

Example 1.6 Suppose x satisfies 2^x=5, prove, by contradiction, that x is irrational.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Revision-of-Proof---Ex1.6.excalidraw



Equivalent Statements
P \iff Q
It can also be said that P is true if and only if Q is true.
This statement states P \implies Q and Q \implies P. To prove an equivalence, both statements must be proven.
Example 1.7 Let n\in\mathbb{Z}, prove that n is divisible by 3 if and only if n^2 is divisible by 3.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Revision-of-Proof---Ex1.7.excalidraw



Alternative Statements



































NameSymbolValueImplicationP \implies QAssume TrueConverseQ \implies PFalseInverse\neg P \implies \neg QFalseContrapositive\neg Q \implies \neg PTrueNegation\neg (P \implies Q) = P \land \neg QTrue

Practice Questions
Ex 3.3 Q4, 5, 7, 12, 14, 15, 21
Ex 3.4 Q3, 5, 10, 11, 12, 14, 17

12SM_2026/01-Proof-and-Logic/03---Induct.title: 03 - Induction
12SM_2026/01-Proof-and-Logic/03---Induct.content:
Induction
Mathematical Induction is the process of proving a statement by showing it is true for the base case, then showing that if it is true for some integer k, then it is true for k+1; it then follows it must be true for all integers greater than the base case.
The steps are:

Show it is true for the base case, usually (but not always) n=1.
Assume there exists some integer k, where the statement holds.
Show that the statement holds for k+1
Conclude that the statement is true for all integers, greater or equal to the base case, usually (but not always) n\in\mathbb{N}


Partial Sums
Example 3.1 Prove the following for n\in\mathbb{N}, using mathematical induction:
\dfrac{1}{1\times2}+\dfrac{1}{2\times3}+\dfrac{1}{3\times 4}+\dots +\dfrac{1}{n(n+1)}=\dfrac{n}{n+1}


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Induction---Ex3.1.excalidraw



Example 3.2 Prove the following:
\sum_{i=1}^{n}(2i-1)^3=n^2(2n^2-1)


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Induction---Ex3.2.excalidraw



Divisibility
Example 3.3 Prove that 7^n-4 is divisible by 3 for all n\in\mathbb{N}


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Induction---Ex3.3.excalidraw



Notation for Products
We have seen previously that infinite or partial sums can be written using sigma notation, \Sigma.
In a similar way, products can be written using pi notation, \Pi.
Example 3.4 Prove the following, using mathematical induction:
\prod_{i=1}^{n}\bigg(1+\dfrac{1}{i}\bigg)=n+1


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Induction---Ex3.4.excalidraw



Inequalities
Example 3.5 Prove, using mathematical induction that 2^n \geqslant n^2 for all natural numbers n\geqslant4.


                  
                  Solution 
                  
                

Transclude of Induction---Ex3.5.excalidraw



Practice Questions
Ex 3.5 Q3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11, 16, 17, 18, 19

Example 2.1 Find the constants a and b such that 1/(k(k+1)) = a/k + b/(k+1), for all k ∈ ℕ.
